name: Sofia
fun_fact: Sofia is home to the stunning Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, one of the largest Orthodox churches in the world with 12 bells (the heaviest weighing 12 tons) all created in Moscow. Bulgaria produces 70-85% of the world's rose oil, with buyers paying upwards of $7,000 per pound. The shopska salad's colors match the Bulgarian flag: white (cheese), green (cucumber), and red (tomato)!

hero_dishes.name: Banitsa
hero_dishes.description: Traditional flaky pastry filled with eggs, white cheese (sirene), and butter, baked until golden and crispy
hero_dishes.origin_story: The quintessential Bulgarian breakfast - when you ask a Bulgarian what they eat for breakfast, many will answer 'banitsa'. The first banitsas come out of the oven as early as 5 AM.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Domashna Banista Bakery near Eagle's Bridge (everything homemade), Rainbow Factory (exceptional homemade banitsa, both savory and sweet seasonal fruit versions), Izbata Tavern, Made in Home

hero_dishes.name: Shopska Salad
hero_dishes.description: Cold salad made with tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, and grated sirene cheese - colors resemble the Bulgarian flag (white, green, red)
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Bulgarian national dish and perfect starter. Created to showcase Bulgarian produce and now served at every restaurant in Bulgaria.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Shtastlivetsa, The Little Things, Divaka, Rakia Raketa Bar, The Hadjidragana Tavern, Manastirska Magernitsa Restaurant, Moma Bulgarian Food and Wine

hero_dishes.name: Kebapche
hero_dishes.description: Grilled minced meat sausages (usually pork and beef) seasoned with cumin and other spices
hero_dishes.origin_story: Beloved Bulgarian street food and tavern staple - often served with shopska salad and a cold beer
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Izbata Tavern, street vendors throughout Sofia, Central Market Hall

hero_dishes.name: Sarmi
hero_dishes.description: Cabbage or grape leaves stuffed with rice and minced meat, slowly cooked
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Bulgarian dish with Ottoman influences, a staple at family gatherings and monastery canteens
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Manastirska Magernitsa (Monastery Canteen - sourced from monasteries across Bulgaria)

hero_dishes.name: Moussaka (Bulgarian-style)
hero_dishes.description: Layers of potatoes and minced meat with yogurt topping - different from Greek version
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bulgarian moussaka uses potatoes instead of eggplant and is topped with yogurt mixture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Made in Home (creative reimagining), traditional taverns throughout Sofia

signature_drinks.name: Rakia
signature_drinks.description: Fruit brandy (usually grape or plum) that's Bulgaria's national spirit
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Drunk as an aperitif with shopska salad to begin a meal. Often homemade and very strong (40%+ alcohol). Sipped, not shot.

signature_drinks.name: Boza
signature_drinks.description: Thick, slightly fermented drink made from wheat or millet with a sweet-sour taste
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The traditional pairing with banitsa for breakfast - 'banitsa and boza' is considered the classic start to a Bulgarian day

signature_drinks.name: Ayran
signature_drinks.description: Salted yogurt drink, cold and refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Perfect with kebapche and other grilled meats, especially in summer

food_culture_notes: Banitsa is eaten for breakfast - buy it steaming fresh in the morning for the crispy outer layer
Every food venue in Bulgaria serves shopska salad - it's the universal starter
Central Market Hall (Tsentralni Hali) is the best place to buy quality Bulgarian cheese directly from producers
Monastery recipes: Manastirska Magernitsa serves curated recipes from monasteries across Bulgaria, including wild boar and rabbit braised in Bulgarian wine
Bulgarian cuisine shows strong Ottoman and Balkan influences
Rose oil and rose products are everywhere - Bulgaria is the world's largest producer

landmarks: Alexander Nevsky Cathedral (gold-plated dome, 45m high, can hold 5,000 worshipers)
atmosphere: Street vendors selling banitsa in the morning
colors: White, green, red of shopska salad (Bulgarian flag colors)
unique_modern: Made in Home's creative takes on traditional dishes
Fusion of traditional recipes with modern presentation
